definitionA: Law. to call or bring before a court to answer to an indictment, a formal charge for which it has been ascertained that there is enough evidence to warrant trial:
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. Arraignment.
<verb>
   1. To officially charge someone in a court of law.
   2. To call to account, or accuse, before the bar of reason, taste, or any other tribunal.
etymology: First recorded in 1275–1325; Middle English arainen, from Anglo-French arainer, Old French araisnier, equivalent to a- a- 5 + raisnier, from unrecorded Vulgar Latin ratiōnāre “to talk, reason”; ratio
example: Hodges was arraigned in 2001 and eventually pleaded guilty to felony commercial burglary.

definitionA: a person who learns late in life
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A person who learns late in life.
etymology: C19: from Greek opsimathēs, from opse late + math- learn

definitionA: a collection of selected literary passages, often by one author and especially from a foreign language.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A collection of written passages, used to learn an unfamiliar language.
   2. A collection of choice passages from an author or authors.
etymology: 1825–35; < New Latin chrestomathia < Greek chrēstomátheia, equivalent to chrēstó ( s ) useful ( chrēs-, stem of chrêsthai to use + -tos verbal adjective suffix) + math- (variant stem of manthánein to learn) + -eia -y 3
example: The Persian text of these fables appeared in 1805 in the chrestomathy appended to Fr.

definitionA: learning in many fields; encyclopedic knowledge.
a manuscript, parchment, or book having writing on both sides of the leaves.
example: Such inscriptions are called opisthograph, that is, written behind.

definitionA: misuse or strained use of words, as in a mixed metaphor, occurring either in error or for rhetorical effect.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A misuse of a word; an application of a term to something which it does not properly denote.
   2. A misapplication or overextension of figurative or analogical description; a wrongly-applied metaphor or trope.
etymology: First recorded in 1580–90; from Latin catachrēsis, from Greek katáchrēsis “a misuse or misapplication of a word or phrase” (derivative of katachrêsthai “to misuse”), equivalent to kata- verb prefix implying waste or consumption + chrêsis “use” (noun derivative of chrê(sthai) “to use, need”) + -sis verbal abstract noun suffix. See cata-, -sis
example: No expression so terse and yet so striking could dispense with the classicism and the catachresis of "stoically."

definitionA: free from living germs or microorganisms; aseptic:
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Unable to reproduce (or procreate).
   2. Terse; lacking sentiment or emotional stimulation, as in a manner of speaking.
   3. Fruitless, uninspiring, or unproductive.
   4. Germless; free from all living or viable microorganisms.
   5. Free from dangerous objects, as a zone in an airport that can be only be entered via a security checkpoint.
   6. Of weapons: foreign-made and untraceable to the United States.
etymology: First recorded in 1545–55; from Latin sterilis “barren, unfruitful”
example: Complete with 348 items, organized neatly into 20 inner compartments, you’ll get a comprehensive kit including 28 sting relief pads, 10 large sterile gauze pads, and one emergency glow stick.

definitionA: an escharotic substance, electric current, or hot iron used to destroy tissue.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. The process of using either extreme heat or extreme cold to either cut or seal body tissue.
   2. A device used for cutting or sealing body tissue.
etymology: 1350–1400; Middle English < Latin cautērium < Greek kautḗrion, equivalent to kautḗr branding iron ( cauterize ) + -ion diminutive suffix
example: Monell, Bigelow, Massey, and Bartholow know electricity about the nose only as a cautery.

definitionA: painted with wax colors fixed with heat, or with any process in which colors are burned in.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A wax-based paint that is fixed in place by heating
   2. A painting produced using this paint
<adjective>
   1. Prepared by means of heat; burned in.
etymology: 1650–60; < Latin encausticus < Greek enkaustikós for burning in. See en- 2, caustic
example: He works in encaustic, a mix of pigment and hot wax that requires a quick hand and whose immediacy has “a sonic quality,” he told a recent visitor to Hemphill Artworks.

definitionA: capable of burning, corroding, or destroying living tissue.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. Any substance or means which, applied to animal or other organic tissue, burns, corrodes, or destroys it by chemical action; an escharotic.
   2. The envelope of reflected or refracted rays of light for a given surface or object.
   3. The envelope of reflected or refracted rays for a given curve.
   4. Caustic soda.
<adjective>
   1. Capable of burning, corroding or destroying organic tissue.
   2. (of language, etc.) Sharp, bitter, cutting, biting, and sarcastic in a scathing way.
etymology: 1350–1400; Middle English < Latin causticus < Greek kaustikós burning, caustic, equivalent to kaust ( ós ) burnt (verbal adjective of kaíein to burn) + -ikos -ic
example: These are endeavors one would be unlikely to attempt without a space to screw things up or spill caustic liquids or explode an engine or two without ruining your carpet.

definitionA: Philosophy.  the theory that whole entities, as fundamental components of reality, have an existence other than as the mere sum of their parts. Compare organicism ( def 1 ).
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A theory or belief that the whole is greater than the sum of the parts.
   2. A practice based on such a theory or belief.
etymology: hol- + -ism; term introduced by J.C. Smuts in Holism and Evolution (1926)
example: Although holism sees human beings as integral organisms, holistic approaches are inclined to have this physical focus.

definitionA: a negative produced by exposing a high-resolution photographic plate, without camera or lens, near a subject illuminated by monochromatic, coherent radiation, as from a laser: when it is placed in a beam of coherent light a true three-dimensional image of the subject is formed.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A three-dimensional image of an object created by holography.
example: The other people’s avatars have clear indicators of their digital nature, whether it’s a generally cartoony appearance or a vaguely translucent nature consistent with what pop culture often presents as a hologram.

definitionA: free from concern, worry, or anxiety; carefree; nonchalant.
etymology: First recorded in 1820–30; from French, equivalent to in- in- 3 + souciant “worrying,” present participle of soucier “to worry,” from Vulgar Latin sollicītāre (unrecorded), from Latin sollicitāre “to disturb”; solicitous
example: Her poems are marked by an insouciant sense of hope, something she sees as a necessity in these times.

definitionA: coolly unconcerned, indifferent, or unexcited; casual:
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Casually calm and relaxed.
   2. Indifferent; unconcerned; behaving as if detached.
etymology: First recorded in 1725–35; from French nonchalant, present participle of obsolete nonchaloir “to lack warmth (of heart), be indifferent,” equivalent to non- prefix meaning “not” + chaloir, from Latin calēre “to be warm”; non-, -ant
example: My son’s nonchalant response to my coming out was one of the greatest gifts I’ve ever received.
